review_title: KSU has become steadily less attractive as an employer for 10-15 years
pros: I was given a paycheck every two weeks.
cons: There is no path to advancement and the only thanks offered for hard work is a longer to-do list while mediocre employees are rewarded with less responsibility for the same pay. Compensation is not even close to competitive. There was a time when medical benefits were fully covered by the university and one could expect a reasonable performance raise every year. Now, the employee contribution for benefits goes up 5% every year and you're lucky to get a 2% pay increase. That doesn't make this a very attractive place to work when the starting salary is already 40% less than you could expect for a similar job role. Unless one had five kids to put through college, it's just not worth it. Every former colleague that I've spoken with since leaving has said the same thing. "It's so much better on the outside."

pros:
The university values diversity, equity, and inclusion
The university is good at recognizing people
cons: The counseling center staff is clickish. It seems the older therapists have a "good ole boys club" and are not inclusive of new staff. In addition, they are focused on individual direct services. So, if you are interested in small groups or outreach, that is discouraged as well as passion and innovation. When you interview, they make promises to get you through the door but reneges on the promises later. Also, if you leave the university before your anniversary, they will make you pay them back because of overpayment. I was never told about this. In fact, I found out because I did not receive my last check. I called payroll to inquire and they did not disburse me my check because I owed them money. Payroll told me they pay employees before they earn their pay which will cause a person to owe them money if they resign before their year anniversary. So, instead of getting my last paycheck, they took it without telling me and told me I owed them more money. Payroll collects on the overpayment as well as expecting you to make full payment within 10 days. I was told I could not use a credit card to pay. In conclusion, if you decide to work at Kent State, make sure you quit on your anniversary so you do not owe them money.

job_title: Student Applications Developer in Kent, OH
pros:
- Great experience in web development, doing everything from front-end to back-end, testing, debugging, and some mobile development that's easily transferrable to a full-time job after college.
- Development stack is pretty up to date (.Net/Angular mostly), which also helps when finding a more full-time position. Also trained us on OutSystems (low-code dev environment) which although pretty new I've seen a lot of jobs pop up using it.
- Very flexible hours
- Pretty low stress
- Everyone understands that it's a temp position until you're able to find a better developer job/intership during/after college, which is a plus.
- Very easy interview, no resume needed, just a couple simple coding exercises and behavioral questions.
cons:
- TERRIBLE pay. $9.70 to start for what is essentially an internship/junior level developer position. It's infuriating considering that the work involves developing, debugging and testing applications used by either a large portion of the student base or an entire department. This is the main reason I'm leaving 3 stars because it clearly shows how much the university values their student employees.
- Sometimes the workload can be a bit low so it can be a bit boring at times, but not the biggest deal.

review_title: Working as a graduate assistant at kent is pretty good.
pros: The best reason to work for kent state is that they generally help pay for school.  I worked for kent state as a graduate assistant, so that was the reason I worked there.  I went to school for free an had got paid about three hundred dollars a month.  Also, working at a college is really nice because the setting is nice, and because you are around smart people.  Kent is a small town, so it is a pretty safe place to work.  There are also lots of shops and restaurants nearby that make it a pleasant place to commute to.
cons: Parking at kent state is terrible.  The parking lots are oversold so that if you are trying to park at a peak time there might not be a place to park.  This is especially true in the winter when some of the spaces are taken up by snow banks.  Kent is not really close to any big cities, so if you are one of the many people that live in that big city you have to drive far to work at kent.  Also the winters in northeast ohio are bad so you might not want to drive very far to work at kent.

The overall rate of enjoyment I get from working at Kent State is very high because I enjoy the carefull environment that the school overs me. cons: The people are pretty incompetant. They all see pretty stupid and unable to handle basic managerial tasks. Overall I'd say that the main reason for dissatisfaction within the working environments of Kent State University are the low payments to student employees, but student employees shoudl expect low pay eveyrwhere because there is so much competition for the jobs available to them. Another donwside to working at Kent State is the silly uniforms.

pros:
Working with Doctor Judge is very easy. I've never had a better boss. His goal is to make the ESL center better, and it definitely shows. Having worked for so long for people who are in it only for the money, seeing someone who works for the students' sake and teachers' sanity is a breath of fresh air.

Getting two years worth of hands-on experience that you can really sink your teeth into is amazing.

Doing the continuing education associated with the ESL center is also really worth it.

There's so much material in the environment it's very easy to turn the surroundings into great,  communicative lessons using authentic language.

Most of the co-workers are great people.
cons:
Some of the students can really wear you down at times, but winning them over is worth it. 

Some of the full-time staff on the other hand can come off as flippant, jaded, and downright inconsiderate.

Your future working there will always be at the mercy of how many ESL students the Office of Global Education recruits.

pros: Working as a graduate assistant will give you some beneficial paraprofessional experience in your field.  However, most places are looking for 1-2 years of experience, this means you're not like to get a job (at least in the current market) unless you've got some really spectacular experiences under your belt.  Get as much as you can as soon as you can, and offer to take up ANY projects that come your way.  These jobs don't pay much, but it can give you experience that other people starting out might not have.  Bosses are very understanding about arranging the schedule around your classes, exams, other jobs, etc.
cons: The pay is kind of awful and sometimes it's hard to get enough hours in.  I had to beg for hours and pick up shifts whenever I could.

review_title: If education is the primary goal, why are we so poorly-paid?
job_title: Adjunct Faculty Member in Salem, OH
pros: Many of the students are eager to learn.
cons: Adjunct pay is below bottom-rung.

job_title: Food Service Worker in Kent, OH
pros: KSU obviously offers flexible scheduling because they realize students have classes and other academic commitments, the paychecks never bounce, there is a variety of jobs to choose from on campus, and they're all well within walking distance.
cons: Sometimes employees find themselves competing with others for a limited amount of workable hours (though this depends on where you work on campus), and normally the shifts are pretty short so you have to work a lot of short shifts a week to make decent money rather than being able to work longer shifts less days per week.

pros: I had a flexible schedule and set my own hours as a tutor; it was great to work on campus between classes. I loved the people I worked with at Student Support Services and felt valued as a worker and as a person. There were many opportunities for continuing education and regular meetings on how to improve tutoring. I found working to help fellow students with their classes very rewarding. I received an hourly raise every other semester and had the opportunity to take extra classes (for free) in order to qualify for more raises.
cons: As a tutor, I was able to set my own hours, but there was a limit to how many hours I worked according to the number of students I saw. If a student did not show up, I would not necessarily be paid for that hour unless there was office work to do. Which classes I tutored and how many students I had depended on what the need for tutoring was that semester. It was frustrating when students would not show up for their scheduled sessions.

pros: I worked on campus in the Center for Entrepreneurship and Business Innovation as an event coordinator and I got a TON of experience that pertained to my job title and also did not pertain to my job title. And I think the best thing about working on campus and being thrown into so many unknown circumstances and situations is that it really helped to prepare me for what life is like after college. A lot (if not all) of my friends had more fun jobs, that paid better, like bartending or waitress, jobs that allowed them to take naps during the day. But looking back I couldn't be more glad that I took a loss on those things and gained experience that eventually lead to better opportunities.
cons: It was sometimes tough to manage my work life and my school life. During certain parts of the year work events required A LOT of attention and were very detail oriented. I sometimes felt torn between the two and often times felt myself applying myself more to work than to school.

pros:
Overall this is an excellent academic institution. The range of degree offerings and students are great. Please note my evaluation is based on exposure to four different academic units within KSU and extensive participation on institute-wide committees and task groups. 

Excellent faculty development and the distance/online education unit is going to be something to take note of. The school's Web group is progressive and provides unparallelled support to all academic units.
cons:
The best and brightest of the university's are passed over or dismissed based on spitefulness rather than merit and contribution to the institution. Tenure should be eliminated or at best subject to a periodic peer based (university and collective bargaining) review.

Academic excellence and honesty should not be sacrificed to filling seats.

job_title: Student Desk Receptionist/CA/Student Auditor in Kent, OH
pros: I have worked for Kent for 3+ years as a student employee. I have worked in 3 different positions, and have loved my experience in each. I really recommend working for Residence Services, I met so many life long friends, and learned many life skills. I currently work for Internal Audit as an Intern, and have really valued the experience. They treat me like a regular full-time employee,  and really expect the same quality work out of me - which I like.
cons: It's pretty tough to live off a student job at Kent, but to be honest they're not really designed for that. Most employees live in student housing, and just use their wages for food and entertainment. I was able to pay rent, and live off my student job but it definitely was stressful at times.

review_title: Good place to work, but very low pay.
job_title: Senior Systems Administrator in Kent, OH
pros:
Really liked the people I worked with other then upper management.
Good benefits and Holiday/Vacation time is awesome!
cons:
Slow to make any changes or implement new ideas until they needed it done 6 months ago. Then its rush to get it done. Consistently moving goal posts, you think you are done with a project but wait there's more. Also, the amount of work you will redo 100 times is laughable or will make you cry. When outages occur, and yes in IT they do. The Management comes down hard on Middle management as if that group didn't already say for the last year Maintenance Items A, B, and C need to be completed or this might happen.

Below average salaries compared to the rest of the universe. Seriously, if you expect to make anywhere near what your other colleagues in IT are making look else where.

pros: Kent State is a great place to work.  The faculty is amazing - professional, supportive, collaborative, and extremely student-focused.  The students are wonderful to work with and very dedicated to their studies.  There is a lot of diversity, a true "melting pot" in Northeast Ohio.  Leadership communicates well, even better than some large corporations that I've worked for in the past.  They are consistently asking for feedback and ways to improve the University.
cons: The only potential negative is that we have outgrown our facilities.  However, leadership is taking all of the necessary steps to accommodate this growth for the betterment of everyone.

review_title: Information Services needs new management. All 3 stars are for benefits
pros: Excellent benefits such as tuition waiver, healthcare, holidays, retirement plan (OPERS)
cons: Information Services management is the worst you will ever see. They have their favorites & if you are not among them, then you can't express yourself. If you dare to do so, be ready for the backlash. They try to cut corners wherever possible. No regular trainings for engineers. Not a comfortable place to work at. I'm here for benefits ONLY. Oh, did I mention, they pay pennies for amount of work you do & skills you possess? DO NOT recommend this place if you are applying for a job in information services -- pathetic pay, terrible management (Hitler style), just good benefits.

pros: Really hard working employees with above average benefits. Very secure jobs once you become established.
cons: Peter Principle everywhere! Lots of chiefs, not enough Indians...very top heavy. The salary/pay ranges for classified/unclassified employees is not even close to the national average. Actually have some employees working below the poverty level!!! Some managers treat their employees like dogs...lawsuits waiting to happen !!

review_title: Kent State Recreation and Wellness Center
pros:
Great environment
Good people

cons: In terms of employment the communication is slightly askew. Several of my cohorts and I have experienced situations where we arrive at work only to come to the realization that we were laid off. The explanation? Either none or a lack of "allocation". These are exemplary individuals who continually set higher goals for themselves.

review_title: Under appreciated, under paid, but at least there is the tuition benefit
pros: Tuition benefits; medical/dental/eye benefits; lived in the community so great commute; really felt like I was helping the students I served. The students appreciated my time and efforts; plenty of opportunity to participate in the campus and local community
cons:
no opportunity for advancement if you do not play the politics. I worked for 11 years in one division and was "tracked" as a civil servant and couldn't get a "professional" position despite the Bachelor's degree I'd earned there.
Gave my blood, sweat and tears and still not enough - as an alumni they contact me for donations.
pay was low

pros: Great environment (beautiful campus); some really great and dedicated people who are focused on the success of the students; flexible and comfortable work environment.
cons: Too much of the 'I'm a phd, I can do this' mentality without seeking proper training and expertise; surprising amount of back stabbing; territorial 'empire' building and subsequent 'topplings'; also surprisingly secretive for a public institution where much is considered 'public record'; not always enough care taken with public funds.

pros:
Students are inquisitive and engaged.
The online library is easy to use.
cons:
-Regional campus faculty are treated like second-class citizens.
- No opportunities for professional development unless tenured.
-No academic freedom. Classes are "canned". Faculty are told to what and how to teach.
-Lack of communication with the same department on the main campus. Excluded from department communications.
-Lack of job security. As non-tenure track faculty, you are given a contract one academic year at a time. At the same time, you are told that you are not allowed to have outside employment without special permission. 
-Favoritism runs rampant. 
-Deans of the program and campus frequently threaten faculty that they will lose their jobs.
-Mediocre instructors keep their jobs because they cower to management.
-The salary for PhD prepared instructor was so low that I qualified for food stamps.
-Enviroment was invalidating. Talents of individuals are not recognized.

review_title: Can't say it's worse than other graduate programs, but still....
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Kent, OH
pros: Some of the faculty in the department are quite supportive.  There's a big push to make sure you find employment after graduation.  A lot of exciting projects, though what you work on is heavily dependent on timing.
cons: Graduate student rights are not formal, so it'll depend on your specific adviser and your department.  Policies were never directly communicated but are expected to be followed.  Very little interaction with others--at least for me, this has felt very isolating.  Pay is horrible.  It seems to me that a lot of money gets wasted on frivolous building projects.

review_title: Overall, staff are helpful, understanding, and care about your career development.
pros: Kent State has a nice campus, with research labs and classes.  The small classes allow for more interaction and the professors have enough time to help you at the individual level.  The stipend is not as competative as some of the other universities, but it is nonetheless enough to live a comfortable graduate student life.
cons: Kent State is on hour south of Cleveland, making it common to have commuters.  It is an additional cost of time and money to drive down for meetings or courses.

pros: Overall Kent is a caring community that strives to improve. It's brand and new strategic initiatives show great promise that better serve employees.
cons: This is a strongly political economy with many actions and decisions being made as power plays vs genuine care to better impact the community. People need to meet and connect with each other more often on a large scale so that we all have an opportunity to be heard.

pros: It's a good place to get your feet wet with teaching experience and the class waiver can be used to further your education.
cons: HORRIBLY disorganized and lower pay than other universities in the area. Standardized curriculums not being released to adjuncts on time (I once got my course information 2 days before the start of semester), failure to process paperwork on time (I didn't receive a contract until 2 weeks into the semester), and it's a royal pain to actually cash in that teaching waiver.

job_title: Graduate Research and Teaching Assistant in Kent, OH
pros: I work with very intelligent people and have a lot of autonomy in what I do. There is a lot of support when it comes to teaching and research, as many people are willing to mentor you. You also get a gym membership for free which is wonderful.
cons: As with all places, there are some bad apples. Mainly the "bad apples" are negative and cynical, but if you work to avoid those people it's not so bad. Also, our stipend is very low and hard to live on.

pros: Wide array of positions, hard working supportive team, relaxed environment, game-day benefits, get to experience the direct effect of the work that is put in.

review_title: Do not have too high of an expectation!
pros: Great people there in the office.
cons:
Employees have no voice and no autonomy. It was clear that the department was working towards their own agenda and forgot that they were there as customer service for the students...they do pay tuition that pays their salary, you know!

review_title: Student Employee / Student Manager- Dining Services
pros: Very flexible with class schedule. Managers have upbeat attitude. Fun, positive experience, easy to bond with fellow employees - which helps in school as well.
cons: Inventory, data management systems are outdated and frustrating. Some of the student employees are not good workers and management simply puts the work on others to pick up the slack.

review_title: Pretty dismal as a long term career choice.
pros: Good medical benefits, free tuition.
cons:
Speaking as an Information Services employee: 

There is absolutely no reward for going above and beyond what is required other than more work to do. 

There is no work from home policy, yet many of us are forced to complete tasks after hours during unpaid overtime or risk being labeled as poor performers for being unable to keep up with our workloads. 

To see any sort of significant increase in salary, the only option is to apply for other positions. This puts the organizational structure in constant flux and makes it difficult to find coworkers with expert knowledge in their current field difficult to find.

The working environment is depressing at best, given that we are all crammed in a small building with little natural light and a bathroom to people ratio of about thirty-five to one. To make matters worse, upper management has specified that on yearly reviews, all employees should average 3 out of 5. The only thing that this promotes is mediocre performance.

Every time we find we way to break up the tedium such as playing harmless pranks on each other or turning on some music, management tosses their wet blanket our way and ruins any sort of motivation that previously existed. 

Most employees here exhibit signs of depression and at least half can be found browsing job sites first thing every morning. Little is done to improve morale and it seems as though the opposite is more likely to happen.

job_title: Adjunct English Instructor in Kent, OH
pros: I had a fantastic doctor at the Health Center and KSU was very good at working with my health issues. I had very little worry about anyone breathing down my neck as far as curriculum development. I was reviewed once a year.
cons: ABYSMAL pay. I had some problem students and when I talked to the University about them, the blame was placed on me and the students did not get help. I actually feared for my health and safety.

pros: Kent State is a world-class University with excellent leadership.  There is a wide range of programs.  Benefit of tuition waiver is huge when you have college-age students - that's the string that keeps me attached for now.
cons: Faculty salaries are very limiting.  You really need to consider outside engagements and summer teaching as well.

pros: It is a university job. There is not much pressure on you. You can do business related projects to help you with your future.
cons: it was all good. i dont have any thing to complain about. but i think they can do more commercials to make a good name in US.

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Kent, OH
pros: Great group of Educators to work with, very dedicated
cons: As a part-time instructor the pay after cost of transportation and parking is under 10/hr for the hours required to complete the job.  If you are passionate it is worth it, if you need to pay your bills it may not be a good choice.

job_title: RN Clinical Instructor in Twinsburg, OH
pros: Sections are at several different clinical sites and they let you choose most of the time, or you can stay at a site you are familiar with.  Sections are usually only one day a week, not divided into 2 days a week
cons: Student groups can get large, up to 10 students per instructor is allowed by The Ohio Board of Nursing, even for critical care courses

pros: great environment to work in with wonderful people and truly meaningful work.  Always felt comfortable to ask for help when needed and found myself looking forward to work everyday
cons: It can be very busy at certain times of the year with students and teachers.  This can lead to additional stress and very short deadlines.

pros: Teach and grad school tuition gets paid. Great deal.
cons: As someone who has experience teaching French in many different places, the KSU French pedagogy program from Elementary I through Intermediate II needs major work. The book is awful, and the evaluations and assessments are unfair and unrealistic. To boot, you are not trained how to teach. I was trained at another institution, but my colleagues and myself were thrown into it with very little guidance.

pros: Processes and policies were defined and clear.  Good benefits and managers were reasonable about amount of work could get done in a day.  Nice variety of work each day so every day is different.
cons: Some employees don't carry their load of work which wears on those that do as all are recognized the same.  Just do your own job and enjoy a good work life balance and great benefits.

review_title: Very good job to have to make extra money while pursuing a degree.
pros: Good balance, always willing to work around student employee's  class schedule. They always made sure that I had no obligations first before scheduling me. Raises given to students  after a full semester working.
cons: None that I can call to mind, overall it was a good job to have. Pay could always be better, but it was just a student job.

review_title: A wonderful place to work part-time
pros: Kent State University's ESL (English as a second language) program is booming, leading to many part-time job openings in the department. The pay is very competitive, teachers are given the freedom to conduct their classes they way they like, and the full-time staff are friendly and helpful.
cons: There is little room for advancement to a full-time position due to high enrollment fluctuations. As needs are difficult to quantify, it is difficult to get approval for more full-time faculty.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: The hours were flexible and the full time staff were very helpful.  My boss cared a great deal about my professional growth.
cons: Not alot really. Parking could be a pain but other than that it was a great place to work as a graduate assistant.

job_title: Spanish Language Instructor in Kent, OH

cons: Parking is difficult to come by and takes a long time to find a spot. Also, part-time positions are available from semester to semester, so you may not know it you will be teaching longer than the term you signed for.

pros: Tuition waiver. Awesome!!!!! Good benefits. Some flexibility.
cons: It is difficult to get acknowledged in this company if you aren't faculty. Too many in upper management and when cuts are made it's with those not in management and then those left are expected to pick up the extra work left due to the cuts.

review_title: Not the Best Place to work
pros: Pro is  Tuition waiver and that if you have live in  partner strait  or Lesbian either way you can get benefits with out being married ..I love working with the student if it were not for them  I'd   left Kent  State  25 years ago ...Money is horrible  hours you work are even worse I work 60 hour weeks every day  is different start time and go home time !!
cons: If you wish to advance at Kent State  expect disappointment they normally higher outside before inside !!  The pay is sub standard there is no raises beyond  the if you lucky standard 2 %  raise every one gets that no matter what level you are Period as long as its approved  the whole  Univ gets  it everyone  !!!!  Benefits eat up most of your paycheck along with Kent  City  Tax and The  Parking  Fees !!!  If you a  work regional Campus job  the pay scale is worse yet the abuse even worse the pay scale almost 3 dollar  lower than a main campus  job !!!  Expect the  pitch fro your lazy boss can you work over tonight were really behind or we did not expect this many to show up !! Soon as you say yes they run out the door leave you high and dry alone !!  If your female your going get even more issues sexual and racial only speaking from experience ..Whats that saying  I been there already  done that  !! There very  micromanagement  work you real hard no reward for your effort you never ever ever get a raise  any different from anyone  in the whole system Period !! I been here 25 years no reason to lie to you ain't get anything more no matter how much leg you show ever !!! I I gave away my 20 year chair twice now plan on ripping up my next  milestone award  january 3 rd only fun  .I ever have is ripping it up in front my  boss face and throwing it in the trash can ..
